Idioms.definition: Which means, cockney rhyming slang for look.
Which means, an offer that is declined now but may be reconsidered later.

Idioms.phrase: Take with a grain of salt
Idioms.definition: Which means, don't take what someone says too seriously - the the implication that it isn't true.
Which means, said when someone that you have just been talking about arrives.
Which means, cockney rhyming slang for thief.
Which means, anticipation of the weekend after a hard working week.
Which means, 1. An expression of sympathy. 2. Said of something that the speaker rates very lowly.
Which means, 1. A scientific test to distinguish between gold and base metals. 2. A conclusive test to determine the validity of a claim.
Which means, someone who is cherished above all others.

Idioms.phrase: The author of your own misfortune
Idioms.definition: Which means, be to blame for one's own problems.

Idioms.phrase: The ball is in your court
Idioms.definition: Which means, it is your turn to make a decision.
Which means, the benefits available from two apparently conflicting options.

Idioms.phrase: The best thing since sliced bread
Idioms.definition: Which means, an outstandingly good idea or plan.
Which means, nickname of the Atlantic Ocean between the UK and the USA.

Idioms.phrase: The bull in the bowler hat
Idioms.definition: Which means, jokey term for artificial insemination.
Which means, the perceived absense of someone who is recently deceased.
Which means, confusion caused by the chaos of battle.
Which means, the 12th of August - the start of the British grouse shooting season.

Which means, an alcoholic drink, intended to cure a hangover. It is mistakenly believed that a small measure of the same drink that made a person drunk will sober them up and cure the drinks ill effects. The expression is also used in other contexts, whenever an additional dose of whatever caused a problem is thought to be an appropriate remedy.
Which means, a state of nervous anxiety or fear.
Which means, enthusiastic Christian believers.
Which means, something that makes a good situation even better.
Which means, the last of a series of problems, which pushes one's endurance beyond its limits.
Which means, the important aspects of a situation; the heart of the matter.

Idioms.phrase: The sound of leather on willow
Idioms.definition: Which means, the sound of the ball on the bat in cricket.

Idioms.phrase: The tail is wagging the dog
Idioms.definition: Which means, a small and usually insignificant factor (or person) dominates over one that is normally more powerful and influential.
Which means, promiscuous woman.
Which means, the full entirety of something.
Which means, said when a previously promising enterprise goes irretrievably wrong.
Which means, said when trying something for the third time.
Which means, the third try is often successful.
Which means, give up, especially to avoid further punishment when facing certain defeat.
Which means, get married.
Which means, a long time to wait.
Which means, cockney rhyming slang for hat.

Idioms.phrase: To cut a long story short
Idioms.definition: Which means, said when a storyteller doesn't want to bore his audience with a long involved account.
Which means, humorously, not to be taken seriously.
Which means, the leading, most important, person in a group or organisation.
Which means, a feat of strength power or skill.
Which means, a woman's much younger male lover.
Which means, cockney rhyming slang for wife.
Which means, refuse to acknowledge something that you know is genuine.
Which means, persuade someone to do something they don't really want to do.
Which means, invitation to go away.
Which means, cockney rhyming slang for state.
Which means, cockney rhyming slang for sick.
Which means, a derogatory term for a black man who is servile towards white men.
Which means, feeling ill.
Which means, having been unable to find a long-term romantic partner.
Which means, on a fruitless course of action.

Idioms.phrase: Up shit creek without a paddle
Idioms.definition: Which means, in serious difficulty, with no hope of respite.
Which means, a saying, usually to a child, after a stumble or fall, to encourage them to get up. (ups is a variant of whoops).
Which means, denoting the enmity between two opposing groups.
Which means, think smart.
Which means, tone deaf.

Idioms.phrase: Variety is the spice of life
Idioms.definition: Which means, increased experience makes for a more exciting life.
Which means, the rhythm method of birth control.
Which means, referring to an item of clothing slipping out of place to expose part of the body.
Which means, 1. Deposited on a beach by the tide. 2. Finished and failed, with no further chance of success.
Which means, a past experience that you prefer not to affect your current life.

Idioms.phrase: Wear your heart on your sleeve
Idioms.definition: Which means, openly express your emotions.
Which means, said of a man with large genitals.
Which means, young and naive, like a new-born baby.
Which means, dirt and muddle are evidence of products being manufactured and money (brass) being made.
Which means, a child or impertinent youth.
Which means, cockney rhyming slang for suit.
Which means, an object that appears magnificent but which is a burdensome financial liability.
Which means, uncultured and lawless.
Which means, deliberately draw attention to something with the intention of causing trouble.
Which means, entertain in a high class restaurant.
Which means, british euphemistic joke.
Which means, 1. Calculate using arithmetic. 2. Take exercise (also spelled 'workout').
Which means, an exact, precisely corresponding to, copy of another's words.
Which means, either 1. Shabby and worn out, or 2. Drunk.

Idioms.phrase: Would you adam and eve it?
Idioms.definition: Which means, cockney rhyming slang for would you believe it?
Which means, referring to something you absolutely refuse to do.
Which means, said of a location that indicates something significant - like a pirate's mark on a treasure map.
Which means, the adorning of public buildings with knitted or crocheted material - either for fun or to make a political point.
Which means, a coward.
Which means, what you eat affects you health.

Idioms.phrase: You can lead a horse to water
Idioms.definition: Which means, you can encourage someone to to do something but, in the end, what they do is their own choice.

Idioms.phrase: You can't judge a book by its cover
Idioms.definition: Which means, decisions can't be made solely on appearance.

Idioms.phrase: You can't teach and old dog new tricks
Idioms.definition: Which means, once animals (and people) are set in their ways they struggle to assimilate new ideas.

Idioms.phrase: You can't take it with you
Idioms.definition: Which means, suggestion that you should spend money and live life now as it will be no use to you after you die.

Idioms.phrase: Your guess is as good as mine
Idioms.definition: Which means, i have no idea.
Which means, you are discredited or in disgrace. The very mention of your name produces scorn.
Which means, it is now your turn. For instance, if 1. You are about to die. or 2. You have won a lottery.
Which means, say nothing; keep your mouth shut. Often shortened to 'zip it'.
